articles.headline: How LinkedIn Became a Place to Overshare
articles.snippet: “This isn’t Facebook,” users complain. But others are finding it a valuable place to talk about much more than work.
articles.abstract: “This isn’t Facebook,” users complain. But others are finding it a valuable place to talk about much more than work.
articles.lead_paragraph: About three years ago, Joel Lalgee started posting on LinkedIn. He works in recruiting, so naturally spent a lot of time on the site, where people list their work experience, and job seekers look for their next gig. But he didn’t just write about work. He wrote about his personal life: the mental health challenges he faced as a teenager, and his life since. “Being able to share my story, I saw it as a way to connect with people and show you’re not alone,” he said.

articles.headline: As India Joins China in Distancing From Russia, Putin Warns of Escalation
articles.snippet: After India’s prime minister said that now is not the time for war, an increasingly isolated Mr. Putin threatened “more serious” actions in Ukraine while insisting he was ready for talks.
articles.abstract: After India’s prime minister said that now is not the time for war, an increasingly isolated Mr. Putin threatened “more serious” actions in Ukraine while insisting he was ready for talks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Underlining Russia’s widening isolation on the world stage, Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India told President Vladimir V. Putin on Friday that it is no time for war — even as the Russian president threatened to escalate the brutality of his campaign in Ukraine.
articles.byline: By Anton Troianovski, Mujib Mashal and Julian E. Barnes

articles.headline: At Mass Grave Site in Ukraine’s Northeast, a Sign of Occupation’s Toll
articles.snippet: Russian troops held the city of Izium, in northeastern Ukraine, for six months. One burial site found this week could hold the remains of more than 400 people, investigators said.
articles.abstract: Russian troops held the city of Izium, in northeastern Ukraine, for six months. One burial site found this week could hold the remains of more than 400 people, investigators said.
articles.lead_paragraph: IZIUM, Ukraine — Hundreds of graves had been cut into the sandy soil of a pine forest, isolated and unexamined. A chilly wind blew through the tree branches. Police officers spoke in hushed tones. And newly dug up bodies lay all about on the forest floor.
articles.byline: By Andrew E. Kramer and Marc Santora

articles.headline: The ‘Wild Field’ Where Putin Sowed the Seeds of War
articles.snippet: In one small town in the Donbas region, everything suddenly fell apart. It was part of Vladimir Putin’s grand plan, and it helped lay the groundwork for the invasion of Ukraine. Now things are heating up again.
articles.abstract: In one small town in the Donbas region, everything suddenly fell apart. It was part of Vladimir Putin’s grand plan, and it helped lay the groundwork for the invasion of Ukraine. Now things are heating up again.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHASIV YAR, Ukraine — On a clear spring morning eight years ago, Oleksandr Khainus stepped outside his house to go to work at the town factory when he spotted new graffiti scrawled across his fence. “Glory to Russia,” vandals had written in angry black spray paint. “Putin,” another message said.

articles.headline: The Subprime Loans for College Hiding in Plain Sight
articles.snippet: Many families can borrow most of the cost of college using a Parent PLUS loan. This will not end well.
articles.abstract: Many families can borrow most of the cost of college using a Parent PLUS loan. This will not end well.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you want your kids to go to college but you can’t afford the bills, the federal government has a deal for you that will blow your mind.

articles.headline: Rally With Trump? Some G.O.P. Candidates Aren’t Thrilled About It.
articles.snippet: Whether he is invited or not, the former president keeps holding rallies in battleground states. It reflects an awkward dance as Republican candidates try to win over general-election voters.
articles.abstract: Whether he is invited or not, the former president keeps holding rallies in battleground states. It reflects an awkward dance as Republican candidates try to win over general-election voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump is preparing to swoop into Ohio on Saturday to rally Republicans behind J.D. Vance in a key Senate race. Two weeks earlier, he did the same for Mehmet Oz in Pennsylvania.
articles.byline: By Michael C. Bender and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: ‘A Crisis Coming’: The Twin Threats to American Democracy
articles.snippet: The United States faces two distinct challenges, the movement by Republicans who refuse to accept defeat in an election and a growing disconnect between political power and public opinion.
articles.abstract: The United States faces two distinct challenges, the movement by Republicans who refuse to accept defeat in an election and a growing disconnect between political power and public opinion.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

articles.headline: Ukraine Wants the U.S. to Send More Powerful Weapons. Biden Is Not So Sure.
articles.snippet: President Biden wants to avoid provoking Russia at a moment when American officials fear Vladimir V. Putin could escalate the war to compensate for recent losses.
articles.abstract: President Biden wants to avoid provoking Russia at a moment when American officials fear Vladimir V. Putin could escalate the war to compensate for recent losses.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Flush with success in northeast Ukraine, President Volodymyr Zelensky is pressing President Biden for a new and more powerful weapon: a missile system with a range of 190 miles, which could reach far into Russian territory.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger, Anton Troianovski, Julian E. Barnes and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Majority of Latino Voters Out of G.O.P.’s Reach, New Poll Shows
articles.snippet: A New York Times/Siena College poll found Democrats faring far worse than they have in the past with Hispanic voters. But overall, the party has maintained a hold on the Latino electorate.
articles.abstract: A New York Times/Siena College poll found Democrats faring far worse than they have in the past with Hispanic voters. But overall, the party has maintained a hold on the Latino electorate.
articles.lead_paragraph: It has been nearly two years since Donald Trump made surprising gains with Hispanic voters. But Republican dreams of a major realignment of Latino voters drawn to G.O.P. stances on crime and social issues have failed to materialize, according to a new poll by The New York Times and Siena College.
articles.byline: By Jennifer Medina, Jazmine Ulloa and Ruth Igielnik

articles.headline: Potent New Covid Boosters Are Here. Will Weary Americans Bother?
articles.snippet: The new vaccine campaign is one of the country’s last remaining strategies, as masks have fallen away and quarantines have diminished. So far, the rollout is methodical but muted.
articles.abstract: The new vaccine campaign is one of the country’s last remaining strategies, as masks have fallen away and quarantines have diminished. So far, the rollout is methodical but muted.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was vaccination time at Ethel Brown’s long-term care home in the Bronx. Again. Ms. Brown, 95, had already gotten four Covid shots, and while she was happy to submit to a fifth, this latest booster prompted a few questions.
articles.byline: By Jack Healy, Sharon Otterman and Amy Qin

articles.headline: Student Loan Subsidies Could Have Dangerous, Unintended Side Effects
articles.snippet: Experts worry that aspects of President Biden’s debt relief plan could lure unscrupulous schools and unknowing students.
articles.abstract: Experts worry that aspects of President Biden’s debt relief plan could lure unscrupulous schools and unknowing students.
articles.lead_paragraph: The centerpiece of the student debt-relief plan that President Biden announced last month is his decision to cancel up to $20,000 per borrower in federal loans. But the more far-reaching — and, over time, more expensive — element of the president’s strategy is his blueprint for a revamped income-linked repayment plan, which would sharply reduce what many borrowers pay every month.

articles.headline: Apple Shot an Oscar Contender Starring Will Smith. That Was Before the Slap.
articles.snippet: The Civil War drama “Emancipation” finished filming early this year. Now, Apple faces a quandary on what to do with the movie.
articles.abstract: The Civil War drama “Emancipation” finished filming early this year. Now, Apple faces a quandary on what to do with the movie.
articles.lead_paragraph: Apple has a Will Smith problem.

articles.headline: Echoing Trump, These Republicans Won’t Promise to Accept 2022 Results
articles.snippet: Six Republican nominees for governor and the Senate in key midterm states, all backed by Donald Trump, would not commit to accepting the November outcome. Five others did not answer the question.
articles.abstract: Six Republican nominees for governor and the Senate in key midterm states, all backed by Donald Trump, would not commit to accepting the November outcome. Five others did not answer the question.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Nearly two years after President Donald J. Trump refused to accept his defeat in the 2020 election, some of his most loyal Republican acolytes might follow in his footsteps.

articles.headline: How Russian Trolls Helped Keep the Women’s March Out of Lock Step
articles.snippet: As American feminists came together in 2017 to protest Donald Trump, Russia’s disinformation machine set about deepening the divides among them.
articles.abstract: As American feminists came together in 2017 to protest Donald Trump, Russia’s disinformation machine set about deepening the divides among them.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

articles.headline: A Welsh Village Embraces Its Bond With the Queen
articles.snippet: A disaster at Aberfan, a small Welsh community, almost 60 years ago forged an unusual link between the community and the queen. The atmosphere there today — quiet grief coupled with brief flashes of dissent — encapsulates the national mood.
articles.abstract: A disaster at Aberfan, a small Welsh community, almost 60 years ago forged an unusual link between the community and the queen. The atmosphere there today — quiet grief coupled with brief flashes of dissent — encapsulates the national mood.
articles.lead_paragraph: ABERFAN, Wales — As the days count down to Queen Elizabeth II’s funeral on Monday, Gaynor Madgwick has been of two minds: Should she watch the ceremony from her home in South Wales or join the crowds in London to pay her respects in person?
articles.byline: By Patrick Kingsley and Mary Turner

articles.headline: Clearview AI, Used by Police to Find Criminals, Is Now in Public Defenders’ Hands
articles.snippet: After a Florida man was accused of vehicular homicide, his lawyer used Clearview AI’s facial recognition software to prove his innocence. But other defense lawyers say Clearview’s offer rings hollow.
articles.abstract: After a Florida man was accused of vehicular homicide, his lawyer used Clearview AI’s facial recognition software to prove his innocence. But other defense lawyers say Clearview’s offer rings hollow.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

articles.headline: The Singular Offense of the Mass Grave
articles.snippet: Violent loss is even more devastating when the dead are disposed of without identification. When Russians pull out in Ukraine, they leave a trail of anonymous death.
articles.abstract: Violent loss is even more devastating when the dead are disposed of without identification. When Russians pull out in Ukraine, they leave a trail of anonymous death.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Every culture wants to memorialize its dead. Every family needs the missing to be identified to reach closure. Perhaps that is why a wartime mass grave offends something so deep in the human conscience.

articles.headline: After Texas Sent Him to Washington, One Migrant Launches a New Life
articles.snippet: Lever Alejos, who was delivered to the nation’s capital courtesy of Gov. Greg Abbott, has found plenty of work. ‘I feel fortunate the governor put me on a bus to Washington.’
articles.abstract: Lever Alejos, who was delivered to the nation’s capital courtesy of Gov. Greg Abbott, has found plenty of work. ‘I feel fortunate the governor put me on a bus to Washington.’
articles.lead_paragraph: When Lever Alejos of Venezuela arrived at the southern border penniless in July, he gladly accepted a free bus ride to Washington, D.C., courtesy of the state of Texas. He had no family or friends to receive him, and spent one night in the plaza across from Union Station. He soon settled into a homeless shelter.

articles.headline: The Story So Far: Where 6 Investigations Into Donald Trump Stand
articles.snippet: The former president finds himself without the power of the presidency, staring at a host of prosecutors and lawyers who have him and his associates in their sights.
articles.abstract: The former president finds himself without the power of the presidency, staring at a host of prosecutors and lawyers who have him and his associates in their sights.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Former President Donald J. Trump has set up his office on the second floor of his Mar-a-Lago estate in Florida as part replica of the Oval Office and part homage to his time in the real White House.

articles.headline: Railroads’ Strategy Thrilled Wall Street, but Not Customers and Workers
articles.snippet: Freight railways pushed to streamline their operations and improve their profit margins. Critics say the approach left the system stretched thin.
articles.abstract: Freight railways pushed to streamline their operations and improve their profit margins. Critics say the approach left the system stretched thin.
articles.lead_paragraph: America’s first commercial railroads were built almost two centuries ago. Freight rail has been a symbol of the nation’s economic might and ingenuity ever since.
articles.byline: By Niraj Chokshi and Peter Eavis

articles.headline: Food Supply Disruption Is Another Front for Russian Falsehoods
articles.snippet: As the war in Ukraine has put pressure on the global markets for food, Russia has spread conspiracy theories that blame the West.
articles.abstract: As the war in Ukraine has put pressure on the global markets for food, Russia has spread conspiracy theories that blame the West.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the Dutch government announced plans in June to reduce certain greenhouse gas emissions by as much as 70 percent, farmers erupted in protest. The change requires sharply cutting the waste produced by livestock operations, potentially forcing some of them out of business. They clogged traffic on highways with their tractors, dumped manure in the streets and set bales of hay on fire.

articles.headline: ‘Crippling’ Energy Bills Force Europe’s Factories to Go Dark
articles.snippet: Manufacturers are furloughing workers and shutting down lines because they can’t pay the gas and electric charges.
articles.abstract: Manufacturers are furloughing workers and shutting down lines because they can’t pay the gas and electric charges.
articles.lead_paragraph: The furnace, heated to 1,500 degrees Celsius, was glowing red. Workers at the Arc International glass factory loaded it with sand that slowly pooled into a molten mass. Nearby on the factory floor, machines transformed the shapeless liquid with a blast of hot air into thousands of delicate wine glasses, destined for sale to restaurants and homes worldwide.

articles.headline: Inflation Remains Voters’ Top Concern. Can Republicans Keep Their Focus?
articles.snippet: Democrats and Republicans are running parallel campaigns, with one party emphasizing abortion and democracy, the other inflation and the economy — and both talking past each other.
articles.abstract: Democrats and Republicans are running parallel campaigns, with one party emphasizing abortion and democracy, the other inflation and the economy — and both talking past each other.
articles.lead_paragraph: Zach Nunn, an Iowa Republican challenging one of the House’s most vulnerable Democrats, had been talking for months about rising prices when a Texas congressman two weeks ago invited him to visit the Mexican border — to see the fentanyl confiscated, hear tales of dying migrants and witness overwhelmed border agents.

articles.headline: On Anniversary of Hurricane Maria, Storm Leaves Puerto Rico in the Dark
articles.snippet: Hurricane Fiona reminded residents that the agonizingly slow work of giving the island a stable power grid remained unfinished.
articles.abstract: Hurricane Fiona reminded residents that the agonizingly slow work of giving the island a stable power grid remained unfinished.
articles.lead_paragraph: SALINAS, P.R. — Hurricane Fiona deluged Puerto Rico with unrelenting rain and terrifying flash floods on Monday, forcing harrowing home rescues and making it difficult for power crews to reach many parts of the island.
articles.byline: By Laura N. Pérez Sánchez, Patricia Mazzei and Erika P. Rodriguez
